title: Thursday, 31st March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Hi there

PM

Bit late, sorry

PM

We got distracted by Bryce finding this repugnant former payday lender guy trolling the good people of Port Talbot

11:02 am
PM

Port Talbot Steel Workers Deserve Everything They Get

BE

Yeah, sorry about that.

PM

Far from a bail out, the people of Port Talbot should be fined and have their steel plant taken off them. They voted for this, now they are going to have to live with the consequences of their decisions.

The MP that these people voted for is one that would inflict the same pain on the rest of the Country given chance. It is about time that people realised the people they vote for has consequences for them. Maybe next time they will think twice, but probably not.

The locals of Port Talbot need to made an example of, if you are a Turkey – don’t vote for Christmas! It’s simple. Throw them under the bus as a warning for the rest of the UK.

11:03 am
PM

https://www.quickl...verything-they-get

BE

And the worrying thing is, it works.

BE

It gets you attention. It can make you president of the USA, potentially.

PM

PM

11:12 am

PM

11:13 am
BE

Well, spiked on results then a week or so later there were all sorts of rumours, which led it to push ever higher.

BE

Think we noted the talk first on March 6.

PM

Ah, was it results that resulted int he spike

11:13 am
BE

The difficulty, of course, is that Fidessa's very expensive.

PM

Yeah, v v high rating

BE

Making it not an obvious PE target, nor an obvious target for a strategic buyer such as Thomson Reuters or whoever.

11:15 am
BE

However, if you believe Mifid II is going to cause havoc, you can also make an argument for Fidessa being on an even higher rating.

BE

Old note incoming from Jefferies, which is house broker.

BE

Alongside a steady recovery in equity end-markets in Fidessa's core regions,
the derivatives business continues to grow rapidly, while greater clarity on
MiFID II regulations is allowing the company to position itself to once again
take advantage of potentially substantial opportunities. Last time regulatory
drivers kicked in, revenue growth exceeded 30% pa. Reinvestment is high, but
it remains the clear leader in sell-side equities.
It has been a relatively tricky few years for Fidessa, with the company suffering
several headwinds to growth. FY15E saw additional churn, including Standard Chartered,
GFI Group and Jefferies Bache. Taken together, the estimated incremental churn increase in FY16E is 2% pts. In addition, the delay to the MiFID II final rules created a temporary spending hiatus, which should be released next year. Forecasts are now conservative, leaving scope for regulatory-driven upside in FY16E onwards.

11:15 am
PM

Of course Mifid will create havoc -- taht's why they've had to delay implementation

BE

Margin drag from new customer additions. Within Fidessa's recurring revenue model,
new contract wins are recognised with a lag, while the investment to bring on customers
is incurred upfront. This trend will have impacted the FY15E adj. EBIT margin to the tune
of 40-50bps yoy. Accordingly, we are expecting a FY5E adj. EBIT margin of 14.0%, which
remains within the stated longer-term range of 13-14%.
Fidessa's efforts to understand the fixed income opportunity continue.
Discussions with potential initial customers are ongoing - any deal in this regard would be a
large enterprise deal along the lines of that signed with Citi and New Edge in the derivatives
segment. "Lighter-weight" options are also being considered to reduce the reinvestment
burden in the short term.
Special dividend is well underpinned. Mgmt notes that after its cash expenditure on
software R&D (37%), capex (18%) and dividends (44%), at least £50m remains unutilized
on the balance sheet. Assuming, for example, £10m annual incremental investment in fixed
income, Fidessa's ability to pay its special dividend would be unaffected for many years.
Valuation/Risks
Fidessa's combination of customer and technology market leadership, high proportion of
recurring revenue (85%), recovering core markets, exposure to higher-growth segments
such as derivatives and proven mgmt track record are the underlying ingredients of a
sustainable valuation premium. The stock currently trades on 2016 PE of 22.9x, a 7%
premium to European software peers on 21.3x. Our 2580p PT is DCF-based. Key risk is
market volatility.

PM

We'll try and do a separate post on this one. Think we might have some further information. wink smile

11:16 am
PM

But don't go nuts

BE

+1. Don't.

PM

(Do you think the machines understand 'dont go nuts'?)

11:17 am

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 781.00, down 12.6 (-1.59%), High: 784.90, Low: 761.10, Volume: 3.26m
11:21 am
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 462.20, down 9.9 (-2.10%), High: 470.95, Low: 458.70, Volume: 1.92m

Anglo's up, though!

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 541.60, up 5.9 (+1.10%), High: 543.00, Low: 509.90, Volume: 3.26m
11:23 am
BE

Interesting from Credit Suisse arguing about it being a stubborn consensus sell.

BE

The market is overwhelmingly bearish on Anglo with more than 70% Sell recommendations compared to less than 30% for the other majors. Yet earnings upside risk is by far the highest in the sector, reflecting: 1) the significant depreciation in the ZAR; and 2) a lack of belief in the company’s cost cutting targets. If the ZAR remains weak (our economists see the recent fall as structural and expect further weakening) and the company delivers on its guidance, the market will need to (begrudgingly) raise estimates.

BE

The sale of phosphates/niobium and the Australian coking coal assets are the most likely near term, in our view, and could raise north of $2bn, taking end 2016 net debt to ~$10bn. From a liquidity perspective the company does not need to raise equity, but from a strategic angle we think once the group has delivered 2-3 material divestments, a $2-3bn equity raise would insulate the balance sheet from lower prices and avoid bottom of the cycle broad based asset sales.

11:24 am
BE

We maintain our Neutral rating. Earnings leverage is high and we expect iron ore prices and diamond sales volumes to correct lower later this year, but we think an overly bearish view on Anglo fails to recognise the evident upside earnings risk for currency and the potential cost savings. The current group strategy envisages a slimming down of the group to 16 core assets across three divisions - diamonds, platinum and copper - and the sale of 60% of the company's assets (or c50% of group EBITDA). To us this appears 'stuck in the middle' between remaining a genuine large scale diversified and a full break up; if the company delivers the targeted cash flow improvements we wouldn’t be surprised to see the strategy modified again with perhaps less aggressive disposal targets.

BE

Still not 100% sure why Anglo doesn't just pull the trigger on an equity raise. Everyone's calling for it.

PM

indeed

11:26 am
BE

Conversations with mining people leave the impression that Anglo management's extremely cautious, in spite of the current strategic plan that's been portrayed as "nearly everything's for sale, make us an offer"

BE

(The assumption being that everything isn't really for sale, but they'll sell what they can and see what they're left with in 2017 when everything might've calmed down a bit.)

undefined
11:27 am
PM

Anything behind Pearson's move?

BE

Nothing I've seen. Asking around.

PM

(No position. We closed our short in the face of a promise to deliver a 6.5% yield...)

11:28 am
PM

The usual hit comes from a US peer warning overnight, but havent seen one this morning

BE

(@mcentral: yep. Exactly. You see the same thing with football clubs that are heading for relegation. "The whole squad is on the transfer list. No one wants them, but that's where they are.")

BE

I guess we can note the Deutsche Bank sell on Pearson, which came out halfway through yesterday but might've only reached desks this morning.

11:30 am
BE

Nothing we've not talked about ad infinitum already though.

BE

We see Pearson as attempting to streamline its business, improve its products
and provide greater value for customer - out of necessity. The rise of Open
Educational Resources has not yet meaningfully impacted the business, but we
think it’s the next challenge Pearson faces and we review it again in this note.
We maintain SELL, TP 770p representing 13% potential downside.

BE

We think Open Educational Resources will change the educational information
marketplace, moving it from a concentrated, high margin oligopoly to a more
diverse, fragmented market with a mix of free and paid-for resources.

11:31 am
BE

Every time we mention open access text we end up mentioning The Company Formerly Known as Reed Elsevier, of course.

PM

Yeah, what is it called now?

PM

Welcome to ML

11:32 am
PM

omg smile

BE

Which is the kind of name you'd give to some kind of Aim website incubator floated in 1997.

BE

Whatever, though. The bear case of open access journals hasn't played out for Reed / Relx.

11:33 am
PM

Rather larger than Pearson, mind

BE

Considerably. About twice the size, as they like to point out.

BE

Back to Deutsche.

11:33 am
BE

Pearson is trading on a 15.8x 2016E PE which we think is high given structural
challenges and revenue decline. For investors who believe in a turnaround, the
2018 multiple is 13.9x, which is only an 8% discount to the European
publishing sector. Given the uncertainty we remain Sell on the shares.

BE

Our Pearson valuation is based on equal-weighted average of 2016 PE &
EV/EBITDA, which we compare to a group of education peers, and DCF, (DCF
assumptions WACC 8.35%, beta 1.0, TG 1.1%). TG is a weighted average of TG
rates at North America, Core and Growth segments.
Risks: accretive acquisitions in areas like virtual schools, online services or in
emerging markets. Other risks include a rise in US unemployment leading to
growth in college enrollments and substantial cost savings from rationalization.

BE

Which was the educational textbook rental company that warned a few weeks ago?

11:34 am
BE

That was an interesting warning.

BE

Gist was that online sales weren't compensating for its normal rental income.

PM

(Greasy wheel -- yes, it's everywhere -- clickbait)

11:35 am
BE

Because, I guess, once you find you can download a textbook for $30, you also tend to find you can download a textbook for free.

BE

And if you're using your university's wifi to do it, all the better.

BE

This isn't that, though. Quick explainer of what we're talking about from Deutsche.

11:35 am
BE

OER are low cost – and in many cases – free teaching materials, used in school
(K-12) or higher education. They can cover core curriculum (which directly
competes with educational publishers like Pearson) as well as supplemental
materials, which are less relevant for paid-for providers. It is important that
OER is not synonymous with free – we have spoken with providers, such as
Open Stax, who offer low cost products, for example $5 digital versions of
textbooks via the Apple store or $30 print-on-demand versions in college
bookstores. The challenge for the incumbents is that low cost alternatives
offer a high quality alternative to highly-priced traditional products.

BE

Yep.

undefined

AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 181.40, up 8.6 (+4.98%), High: 198.00, Low: 181.00, Volume: 1.19m
PM

Pre close statement here http://www.investe...1603310700096236T/

PM

Our UK business performed strongly during the fourth quarter with revenue and EBITDA ahead of our expectations as we continued to gain market share. As a result, we expect full year UK revenue growth to be c.18.5% with revenue growth from AO.com to be c. 27% and UK adjusted EBITDA to be c. £17m. Expectations for the UK business in the next financial year remain unchanged.

11:37 am
BE

BE

BE

11:39 am

So we learn today that it's gaining market share and gaining awareness -- both what you'd expect from advertising.

BE

BE

Here's Cazenove.

11:39 am
PM

Who are the house

BE

Indeed they are.

BE

AO has reported a pre-close trading update for the year ended 31 March 2016.
UK FY16 revenue and EBITDA are both ahead of expectations, reflecting
increased brand awareness and ongoing market share gains. European
EBITDA is also slightly better than expected. In FY17, management
expectations in the UK are unchanged, and in Europe, it plans to focus on
achieving operational efficiencies ahead of accelerating volume growth post
the move to its new European warehouse later in the year.

11:40 am
BE

 UK ahead of expectations. FY16 UK revenue of +18.5% yoy is ahead of
our expectation for +16%, driven at least in part by improved brand
awareness, which continues to steadily increase. Within UK revenue, FY16
AO.com sales grew by c.27% yoy (JPMe +26%). This implies Q416
AO.com growth of c.+26%, ahead of our forecast for +22%. FY16 UK
EBITDA is expected to be £17m (and would imply a margin of 3.0%),
ahead of our forecast for £15.6m (JPMe 2.8% margin), driven by the better
sales performance and small efficiencies across a number of cost lines. We
raise our FY16 UK EBITDA forecast to £17m (from £15.6m). We leave our
FY17 UK EBITDA forecast unchanged at £22m (implying a margin of
3.3%), in line with management guidance.
 European sales in line and EBITDA to be slightly ahead. European
revenue (effectively Germany for FY16 with the Netherlands having started
trading on 1 March 2016) is expected to be within the current range of
expectations (JPMe £44m). EBITDA is expected to be slightly ahead of
forecasts helped by a focus on efficiencies. We reduce our FY16 forecast
for a European EBITDA loss to -£20.7m (previously -£22.6m).
 FY17 European focus on operational efficiencies. Ahead of the group’s
move to its new European warehouse later in the year, it is taking the
opportunity to focus on operational efficiencies. We expect this to include
moving away from more costly agency drivers and hire trucks to employed
staff and leased vehicles, for example. We believe AO is effectively laying
the foundations for an efficient acceleration in volume growth once the new
warehouse is open. We leave our FY17 European EBITDA forecast for a
loss of £17m broadly unchanged but update the shape of our estimates. We
reduce our FY17 European sales forecast to £90m (from £123m), but expect
this to be fully offset by lower distribution costs and opex (rather than the
bought-in gross margin which we do not expect to materially improve ahead
of significantly higher volumes).

BE

And Numis, which is also house isn't it?

BE

Floated back when Numis was on every single ticket.

11:41 am
PM

Think so yes

BE

AO has posted a strong Q4 ahead of our forecasts, such that FY UK revenue growth
is expected to be c.+18.5% (NSe +16.5%), with AO.com c.+27% (NSe +25%). As a
result, FY UK EBITDA is expected to be c.£17m, ahead of our estimate of £15.9m.
While we cautiously leave our FY17 UK estimates unchanged at this stage, and
factor in a lower top-line growth rate in Europe as management drives efficiencies
in the short term, we see this is an encouraging update. We retain our positive
stance, confident that AO's leading customer proposition can support long term
profitable growth in the UK and internationally.
● Good growth in Q4: The FY outturn implies Q4 AO.com growth of +24%, continuing
the much improved trend since Q1 (+11%), albeit somewhat slower, as expected, than
Q2 (+32%) and Q3 (+35%), which benefited directly from the major brand-building
investment. This performance was driven by business-wide improvements in efficiency
and execution, and the continued flow-through benefits of the brand-building exercises
undertaken earlier in the year.

BE

● We cautiously leave FY17 unchanged at this stage: As a result, FY UK EBITDA
is expected to be c.£17m, ahead of our estimate of £15.9m. Despite the solid Q4, we
leave our FY17 UK estimates broadly unchanged at this stage, mindful that, as a high
growth company, quarterly trading will be somewhat volatile, and that the short-term
tactical competitive environment can change quickly. Nevertheless, we are encouraged
by the trading momentum the business has re-built in its core market and welcome the
change in direction of forecasts.
● Focused on 'driving efficiencies' in Europe: Turning to Europe, where the
Netherlands launched on 1st March, management notes that it expects FY revenue to
be within the current range of expectations, but for EBITDA to be slightly better as it
focuses on ‘driving efficiencies’. In our view, this reflects a sensible pragmatism to 1)
ensure the business is operating as efficiently as possible before the new Bergheim
DC opens later this year, which will see a material ramp-up in growth, and 2) AO is not
forcing unprofitable volumes, given that product margin gains are likely to take time,
as well as scale, to achieve. While this stance is likely to see somewhat slower top-line
growth in the short term (we lower our FY17 forecast from £120m to £100m), AO will
have a firmer, more efficient platform from which to build. Meanwhile, our confidence
is as high as ever that AO can achieve its product margin aspirations over time.

11:42 am
BE

Briefly, from David Reynolds at Jefferies ......

BE

What do we think? A robust close to the year, but as always, we shouldn't try to make too much of one quarter, the tempo of AO's business is certainly not quarterly. AO is managing the business in a pragmatic, measured and controlled fashion. There is a growing confidence around the UK and continued learnings in Europe.

BE

Can't find a seller immediately. So it's up to me to say that it can still be seen as quite expensive for a company doing a 3% margin that's expected to be lossmaking for at least the next two years.

11:45 am
BE

Jefferies again:

BE

Valuation. AO trading on 0.8x 17 EV/Sales, versus the peers on 1.1x, similar 14/17 sales CAGRs, +25.4% and +25.3% respectively.

BE

EV/sales multiples. Cool.

The Company announces that on 30 March 2016, David Potts, Chief Executive Officer, purchased 180,000 ordinary shares of 10 pence each ("Shares") in the Company on the London Stock Exchange at a purchase price per Share of 201.62p. His total shareholding following this purchase is 1,002,881 Shares.

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 200.90, down 1.2 (-0.59%), High: 202.20, Low: 199.70, Volume: 1.90m
11:51 am
undefined
PM

Still very much an easter feeling in London

BE

This Enquest upgrade from Macquarie was requested earlier. Happy to help.

11:52 am
BE

This report deep-dives into PMO, ENQ and CNE, each of which is completely reliant on the Catcher/Kraken projects. We recommend buying Cairn (12% potential upside) and EnQuest (220% potential upside) as part of a balanced basket of E&P stocks. We would avoid Premier until near-term balance sheet hurdles are overcome.

BE

220% potential upside!

EnQuest PLC (ENQ:LSE): Last: 23.75, up 3.75 (+18.75%), High: 24.25, Low: 20.00, Volume: 5.82m
11:52 am
Premier Oil PLC (PMO:LSE): Last: 43.13, down 0.625 (-1.43%), High: 43.50, Low: 40.50, Volume: 4.19m
Cairn Energy PLC (CNE:LSE): Last: 198.80, down 3.2 (-1.58%), High: 202.20, Low: 198.60, Volume: 228.00k
BE

So ..........

11:53 am
BE

Cairn’s balance sheet is the strongest, although additional funding would be needed to fund Senegal development at 40%. Near term, Premier’s balance sheet exhibits the most risk on covenant issues – its future is in the banks’ hands. EnQuest looks safer, with no near-term balance sheet triggers. Its future is contingent on operational delivery (and therefore in its own hands).

BE

Investing in either EnQuest or Premier is substantially an investment in either Kraken or Catcher due to the centrality of these projects to the stories.
 Point forward, Kraken looks better from both cash netback and IRR metrics. However, given proximity of the metrics, operational delivery will be the driver of which project ends up underpinning the better investment.
 To date, EnQuest has delivered 13% reduction to Kraken capex versus c.0% by Premier on Catcher. Future costs savings could materialise for both projects if the operators don’t to go into contingency budgets: news flow here is likely to materialise sooner for Kraken than Catcher due to project progress.
 From similar original First Oil dates, we now expect Kraken to start producing six months before Catcher; progress has been better so far.

PM

(Good point doodle)

11:53 am
BE

Cairn is the only one of the three stocks with substantial alpha value creation catalysts. EnQuest has no near-term balance sheet triggers, so negatives should be limited. Kraken FPSO sail away in September 2016 is the key operational event. There are limited additional catalysts that we can pinpoint, which makes this even more of an oil price leverage investment. Premier’s share price drivers are mostly finance related, but could be either positive or negative and are out of Premier’s hands. We estimate a potential 67% upside, offset by a potential 54% downside, suggesting further share price volatility is possible.

BE

So in terms of recommendations ..............

BE

 Cairn (TP raised to 229p from 228p) from offers near-term value creation potential plus a defensive element. We are buyers into upcoming catalysts.
 EnQuest (recommendation raised to O/P from N) offers attractive leverage to an oil price recovery, which we are confident will happen over the next 12 months (however, it may be better to wait for near-term oil price weakness to materialise before buying.Financially, the business should survive, and recent operational updates have been impressive. This, combined with acceleration of our Kraken First Oil assumption drives our TP increase from 24p to 64p.
 We downgrade Premier to Neutral ahead of approval of the E.ON transaction. We adjust our Fair Value down to 44p (from 144p) on balance sheet concerns. Pre-adjustment NAV remains high at 133p, but the risks to be overcome before accessing this oil price leverage are too high, in our view, especially when EnQuest offers similar leverage, but with fewer risks.

11:54 am
BE
